doc/source/configuration/policy-concepts.message: this if for POST,DELETE,PATCH ARQ APIs, FIY: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cyborg/Policy

It is project_member_api. 
system_admin_or_owner is for arq POST/DELETE/PATCH usage.
For example, project_member_api is the minimum policy requirement to DELETE an arq. this means any user, with a member role and who has the same project_id with that of arq, can do the DELETE arq operation. Here we add system_admin as an OR policy, is because system_admin should be also able to have the superpower to do this operation.
Moreover, project_member here already implied that a project_admin is also able to do this operation as keystone already support implied roles: pls see in the NOTE of https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/cyborg-specs/specs/victoria/approved/policy-defaults-refresh.html#rest-api-impact

Treat the activated as added. But I have a question need to be clear here, if we just create a port binding, not activate. Then the first loop, agent will prepare the necessary port resources, such as port add into the linux bridge/ovs-bridge. This is to handle the case where the vif has been added to br-int by Nova but the binding is inactive for that host. We want the agent not to wire the vif until the binding is activated

Before this change:

if not 'port_id' in details

meant that the port or its binding wasn't found in the neutron server through the RPC call in L1537 above. As a consequence, even though the agent has found a corresponding VIF connected to br-int, we are going to set it up as a dead port, because we don't know anything about it and we don't want to create a security risk. By setting the port as dead, we prevent it from being able to listen to traffic in br-int
<------ Please see at my comment on the left side of the screen

After this change, we have a new case. We found the port and its binding in the neutron server through the call in L1553 above, but:

1) not 'port_id' in details and
2) c_const.NO_ACTIVE_BINDING in details

so we know the active binding is not in this host: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/rpc.py#L297:L303. The instance that uses this port is most likely being migrated and is in step 2 as described in this commit message: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/574058/15//COMMIT_MSG. In the near future (step 3 of the previously mentioned commit message) a binding will be activated in this host. But until that happens, we also have to set up the port in this host as dead, because, again, we don't want to create a security risk. When the binding is activated, the VIF / port will be correctly re-wired by the agent because it will be treated as a newly added VIF / port. Please see L429-433 and L479-483 above....
.... but we still have the old case, where the port wasn't found in the neutron server. We still have to set this port as dead

ceilometer/publisher/gnocchi.py.message: How does moving this line inside the next loop change the behavior? Inside the loop resource_id is not changed.

Sure. I just did. Thanks for the review.

Side note, it is not just about Neutron, it is about Unhandled metrics that do not have resource_id. We should not care if they have the proper expected format as they are unhandled/discarded.

can we please add a unittest for this?

Just to make sure we don't break it in a next commit?
Also to make sure this doesn't break anything outside neutron?

Line 343 `rd = self.metric_map.get(metric_name)` will try to get the resource definition. If the resource is not allowed pushes to Gnocchi (or some other backend), then it is going inside the conditional at line 346, which makes us hit the continue at line 351.

Did you understand? 

If the `resource_id = resource_id.replace('/', '_')` is placed above line 345, we will be processing `resource_id` even for metrics of resources that we do not want to push to the backend, which may lead to errors like the one I am describing in the commit message with the newly and merged implementation of Neutron granular network metering agent.

When an operator will add a host to a segment, hostname can be  a FQDN or just hostname, for example, juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18.project.serverstack or juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18.

If it's a FQDN i.e. juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18.project.serverstack, it will pass the validation becoz of your changes, but when it will be stored in the masakari 'host' db table in 'name' column' it will be stored as "juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18.project.serverstack" only. 

So now, it will expect masakari-monitor to send notification with 'host_name' parameter as "juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18.project.serverstack" only instead of "juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18". If it's uses hostname i..e , "juju-f4bd71-zaza-9db566d782a2-18", notifications will not be processed.

But I assume when operator will configure pacemaker and add nodes to it, it will alway be hostname and not FQDN. so in real production, it will always work.

neutron/agent/linux/dhcp.py.message: We've now trashed option, so if neither case is true below that will cause problems on L1138, right?
Ack, thanks for the answer.  Looks like I was theorizing on something that couldn't happen based on the arguments that are passed.

I don't believe so, no: if the option name *doesn't* start with `(encap:(\d+),)`, then the match is everything after that optional capture, i.e. the whole string. So, `option = option`, in a sense.

It's not how I would write this code myself, to be honest. However, I took the approach that was/is already present in the code to match on `tag:...` earlier in the function.

Also, I'd expect unit-tests to fail if option-without-encap would be captured/handled incorrectly?
Is this just the original option, i.e. before L1129?

Yes, except that we kinda validated the argument to `encap:...` is one-or-more digits, which it needs to be anyway to be a valid argument to dnsmasq's `dhcp-option`.

Again, this is likely not how I'd write this code myself, but I repeated the pattern used for `tag:...` parsing above.

neutron/tests/common/exclusive_resources.message:
Here you need the path, so you need to retrieve it from the fixture:
  temp_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()).path

You need to move this to _setUp(), because the parent fixture (ExclusiveIPAddress, ExclusivePort, etc) must execute first the setUp() method to call self._clear_cleanups(), to initialize the self._cleanups member.

This could be something like:

class ExclusiveResource(fixtures.Fixture):
    def __init__(self, resource_name, allocator_function, validator=None):
        self.resource_name = resource_name
        self.allocator_function = allocator_function
        self.validator = validator

    def _setUp(self):
        temp_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()).path
        self.ra = ResourceAllocator(
            self.resource_name, self.allocator_function, temp_dir,
            self.validator)
        self.resource = self.ra.allocate()
        self.addCleanup(self.ra.release, self.resource)
Thanks Rodolfo, I'll give that a try!

Now I review the purpose of ResourceAllocator, I have concerns about this patch.

All resources are stored in the same path with unique file names, depending on the resource. When a process wants to access to this resource, it only needs to know the resource name but not the path. If the path is created randomly by TempDir [1], other processes won't have this reference path available and won't be able to access to the resource.

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/746450/

We don't need this function anymore. The resources are freed when the temporary directory is deleted and this is done "automatically" because this directory is a fixture (with its own cleanUp function)

temp_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()).path



This function should be:

  def release(self, *args):  # *args to avoid pep8 errors
                             # for unused param.
      pass

I can see how the dir/file would get cleaned-up, but the resource won't be released for another instance to use.  Maybe I'm missing something.

These small, seemingly simple changes are always a pain...
Thanks for this info, I've let this change get old, but i'll send an update.

That's the point: the resources are stored in files under this tempdir. When the tempdir is deleted, those resources will be "freed". This last sentence is not accurate, because ResourceAllocator is just an information blob made permanent in the filesystem, nothing else.

In L106, because at this point the tempdir is already gone, you'll have always None. That's why this implementation is failing.
You forgot about "return" here and probably this causes failures of many functional/fullstack tests

There is a use-case, when a member and LB needs to have an Norh-South connectivity.
For example there is a managing station that has connectivity to member via its FIP and also there is a need to have LB traffic to be exposed also with FIP. This is standard Octavia use-case.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message: change the output to NORMAL,so the gateway_mac will be learned.

Now we are depending on the local qr- interface sending packets to the vms. But this does not happen often because the routing between vm1:host1:sub1 <-> vm2:host2:sub2 is asymmetric and the return packets of a tcp flow take a different path:

(host1: vm1 --> ovs --> qrouter --> ovs) --> tunnel --> (host2: ovs --> vm2)

(host2: vm2 --> ovs --> qrouter --> ovs) --> tunnel --> (host1: ovs --> vm1) 

The only packets I see from qr- to vm are arp responses. I don't think we should be relying on the vm making arp requests for the gateway. I ran an iperf test with -t 400 and after 300s the gateway mac gets aged out of the mac table and flooding starts.

jenkins_jobs/modules/parameters.py.message:
This should be "(default: "") according to the code below.

The way we use the word "(optional)" in JJB would be when the mapping is something like this:

 mapping = [("name", "name", None)]
 helpers.convert_mapping_to_xml(..., fail_required=False)

Note the `fail_required=False` as what this does when matched with a "None" mapping is skips generating the XML altogether.

In cases where a blank string like ("") is being passed this should be documented as (default: "") as a blank string is being passed in.

(This comment applies to the other 3 "optional" config below too)

jenkins_jobs/modules/properties.py.message:
Instead of coding like this, I suggest using the convert_mapping_to_xml and spelling out the optOut parameter as a parameter of the plugin.

While this plugin only accepts one parameter as the top level config for now, we have seen cases in the past where a later version of similar plugins added additional parameters restructuring the XML layout. So using the convert_mappings function will future proof this property. Also it adds some common error checking conditions too which is helpful.

I'm not sure I'd ask you to change anything here, I'm just trying to add context.

-1: However, this is a change in that currenly, if no one says anything at all about timeouts (in main.yaml or in any jobs), there is no timeout, but with this change, we'll get the default of 10800.  So we should mention in the upgrade note that if you want to maintain the status quo of no timeouts, you should set tenant.max-job-timeout to -1.

I found out why I need it after doing more testing

http://paste.openstack.org/show/798244/

I am testing with line 199 commented out (which is where lines 189 to 194 are applied to the payload map). When I did this a few months ago it was necessary. Let's see what happens when it's not there today.

So that the Glance service knows which cephx keyring to use when connecting as a client to the appropriate external Ceph cluster.

E.g. for dcn0 it would result in /etc/ceph/central.conf being created with the following:

[client]
keyring = /etc/ceph/central.client.external.keyring

It seems to be working without it. I'll prepare a patch set without those lines. If that's your only objection, then maybe we can merge this with those lines removed and then if after more testing I find that they are needed I'll do a follow up patch.

We should confirm it's truly needed because it's specifically added to glance's multistore backend config by [1]. The default value comes from [2] via [3], and the multiconfig value comes from [4].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/src/branch/master/manifests/profile/base/glance/backend/rbd.pp#L102
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/src/branch/master/manifests/profile/base/glance/backend/rbd.pp#L62
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml#L485
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/src/branch/master/manifests/profile/base/glance/backend/rbd.pp#L102

I don't know exactly how glance uses the rbd_store_user parameter, so it's possible the override is required?
I don't recall whether this is a current limitation that may be lifted. If it might then this hard-coded value will need to be reworked.

Yes, in theory it's possible it would need to be reworked. This is to configure a ceph client, not a ceph server. If for someone reason we needed to re-work this we could. At the moment if you omit it then the deployment will fail.
